comment.text: Catalyzes two distinct but analogous reactions: the reversible epimerization of UDP-glucose to UDP-galactose and the reversible epimerization of UDP-N-acetylglucosamine to UDP-N-acetylgalactosamine. The reaction with UDP-Gal plays a critical role in the Leloir pathway of galactose catabolism in which galactose is converted to the glycolytic intermediate glucose 6-phosphate. It contributes to the catabolism of dietary galactose and enables the endogenous biosynthesis of both UDP-Gal and UDP-GalNAc when exogenous sources are limited. Both UDP-sugar interconversions are important in the synthesis of glycoproteins and glycolipids.

kinetics.KM: 69 uM for UDP-galactose (at 37 degrees Celsius and pH 8.8)
kinetics.Vmax: 1.22 mmol/min/mg enzyme with UDP-galactose as substrate

disease.name: Epimerase-deficiency galactosemia
disease.description: Clinical features include early-onset cataracts, liver damage, deafness and mental retardation. There are two clinically distinct forms of EDG. (1) A benign, or 'peripheral' form with no detectable GALE activity in red blood cells and characterized by mild symptoms. Some patients may suffer no symptoms beyond raised levels of galactose-1-phosphate in the blood. (2) A much rarer 'generalized' form with undetectable levels of GALE activity in all tissues and resulting in severe features such as restricted growth and mental development.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.

Contrary to the human enzyme, the E.coli ortholog (AC P09147) does not catalyze the epimerization of UDP-N-acetylglucosamine to UDP-N-acetylgalactosamine. Compared to the E.coli enzyme, the sugar-binding pocket of the active site is 15% larger for the human enzyme, making it possible to accommodate the acetyl group.
Belongs to the NAD(P)-dependent epimerase/dehydratase family.

property.value: Defective GALE can cause Epimerase-deficiency galactosemia (EDG)

feature.description: In EDG; peripheral; nearly normal activity towards UDP-galactose; dbSNP:rs121908046.
In EDG; 800-fold decrease in UDP-galactose epimerization activity; dbSNP:rs28940882.

In EDG; generalized; 30-fold decrease in UDP-galactose epimerization activity; 2-fold decrease in affinity for UDP-galactose; 24% of normal activity with respect to UDP-N-acetylgalactosamine; dbSNP:rs121908047.
In EDG; 7-fold decrease in UDP-galactose epimerization activity; very mild decrease in activity towards UDP-N-acetylgalactosamine; dbSNP:rs28940883.
In EDG; peripheral; 3-fold decrease in UDP-galactose epimerization activity; dbSNP:rs121908045.
In EDG; 7-fold decrease in UDP-galactose epimerization activity; does not affect affinity for UDP-galactose; dbSNP:rs28940884.
In EDG; 6-fold decrease in UDP-galactose epimerization activity; very mild decrease in activity towards UDP-N-acetylgalactosamine; dbSNP:rs3180383.
In EDG; nearly normal activity towards UDP-galactose; mild impairment under conditions of substrate limitation; dbSNP:rs28940885.
In EDG; 2-fold decrease in UDP-galactose epimerization activity; dbSNP:rs368637540.
No effect on activity towards UDP-galactose. Loss of activity towards UDP-N-acetylgalactosamine.
